s.text: A big part of legal aid's success depends on pro bono, or free, work by lawyers.
Balmer grabbed the paper that he had jotted notes for his speech on and abandoned his neck tie and formerly reliable vehicle.
Oregon is meeting 18 percent of the need for civil legal services to low-income Oregonians, according to a Legal Need Study.

It had been a long time since he flagged a ride with his thumb, but he was desperate.
When an Oregon Supreme Court Justice arrived at Central Oregon's Office of Legal Aid Services Wednesday evening about 30 minutes late and with wind-blown hair, nobody thought much of it.
Then again nobody attending an open house to discuss legal aid funding and service issues in the state knew exactly what Thomas A. Balmer went through to give a speech on the subject.
